content: The child nutrition programs, managed by the USDA-FNS, include the NSLP, SBP, Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Program, Special Milk Program, and Child and Adult Care Food Program, providing meals and snacks in institutional settings like schools and child care facilities. The child nutrition programs, including NSLP, SBP, Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Program, Special Milk Program, Child and Adult Care Food Program, and Summer Food Service Program, were last reauthorized by the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010. Some authorities expired on September 30, 2015, but had minimal impact on program operations. It highlights recent issues raised by Congress and program stakeholders, drawing examples from legislative proposals in the 114th and 115th Congresses. Schools participating in the National School Lunch Program (NSLP) and/or School Breakfast Program (SBP) must comply with federal requirements to purchase domestic commodities or products to the maximum extent practicable under the Buy American requirements. Under Buy American requirements, schools in the NSLP and/or SBP must buy domestic commodities or products produced and processed substantially in the US, as defined by statute and USDA guidance. "Processed substantially" means the product is processed in the United States with over 51% domestically grown ingredients, as defined by USDA guidance. The Buy American requirements apply to any foods purchased with funds from the nonprofit school food service account, as outlined in USDA regulations and guidance. The June 2017 memorandum outlines Buy American requirements for foods purchased with funds from the nonprofit school food service account.
